Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the local office at (248) 975-5053.

II. ALLEGATION(S):
Violation
Established?
The facility is not maintained in a safe condition Yes
Resident Z's door to room has been broken since his arrival 6 weeks prior. Other
residents keep entering his room and assaulting him. Staff do not intervene but
call for security while he is being assaulted. Staff are aware of the broken lock
and have not addressed it. Resident Z has multiple injuries from recent a recent
assault requiring medical attention.
III. METHODOLOGY

2021C0108010

Resident Z to a room that locks; scheduled phone interviews due

11/17/2020 Contact - Telephone call made
Interviewed Resident Z, Staff 1 and Therapist 1 via phone due to
COVID-19 restrictions; requested maintenance/part order for door
11/23/2020 Exit Conference
With CA and Center Director 1 via telephone
ALLEGATION:
Resident Z's door to room has been broken since his arrival 6 weeks prior.
Other residents keep entering his room and assaulting him. Staff do not
intervene but call for security while he is being assaulted. Staff are aware of
the broken lock and have not addressed it. Resident Z has multiple injuries
from recent a recent assault requiring medical attention.
INVESTIGATION:
I interviewed Resident Z, age 15, on 11/17/20 via telephone due to the COVID-19
pandemic. He said he was transferred three weeks ago from Pineview Homes to
2

Lincoln Center. Resident Z is a DHHS/JJ contracted youth in placement for charges of
Resisting Arrest and Assault on a Police Officer.
Resident Z explained how the lock on his bedroom door would stick. He told a few staff
and his therapist about it. Sometimes it would not lock on its own and the staff had to
manually use their key. Yesterday (11/16/20), Resident Z confirmed that the lock on his
door had finally been fixed.
On 11/14/20 at 9am before the lock was fixed, Resident Z said Resident N threw a chair
into his room. “I came out. Resident N pushed me and I pushed him back. He started
hitting me in the back of the head where my shunt is. Another kid told him to stop.
Security came and put Resident N in his room.” Resident Z said Staff 1 was working
alone on the pod with 7 youth when this happened.
After the assault, Resident Z said he saw the facility’s nurse and was given ice for his
head. Then the following morning, he was taken to Children’s Hospital and diagnosed
with a Head Contusion.
I interviewed Staff 1 who has worked at the facility for over six years. He acknowledged
Resident Z’s room door did not always lock properly. Staff 1 said he submitted a
maintenance request to have the door fixed but had no record of it. “It’s been broken
before,” he added.
Staff 1 said he was working on the pod the morning of 11/14/20 but did not see anyone
throw a chair into Resident Z’s room. “I was passing out breakfast and the kids called
my name. I saw Resident N hitting Resident Z in his head or chest area. I called for
security…I separated them. I think security came in and assisted.” Staff 1 could not
recall what security officer or officers arrived; or if staff separated the youth or the
aggressor stopped on his own. “I noticed Resident Z’s nose bleeding and called the
supervisor and nurse. The nurse looked at him within minutes.”
I interviewed Therapist 1 who has worked at the facility for eight months. She said
Resident Z mentioned to her that his door only locked with a key while the other youth’s
doors locked when shut. Therapist 1 said she repeatedly asked direct care staff (on
10/29, 11/5 and 11/12) to move Resident Z to a vacant room because his door was not
locking properly. “There was an open room on the pod but they (staff) never switched
his room,” she explained.
3

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4407 Facility and premises maintenance.
(1) A facility and premises shall be maintained in a clean,
comfortable, and safe condition. The facility shall be
located on land that is properly drained.
ANALYSIS: Sleeping in a room that did not consistently lock when it was
shut posed a safety risk to Resident Z. Facility staff including
the Center Director were aware of the malfunction for several
weeks. The therapist said she requested Resident Z be moved
to another room for three consecutive weeks but the staff failed
to facilitate the change. A part for the door was ordered and the
lock was repaired on 11/16/20. However, on 11/14/20 another
resident threw a chair into Resident Z’s room and then
assaulted him. The facility did not keep Resident Z safe by
knowingly keeping him in a room that did not properly lock.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Once an acceptable corrective action plan is received, I recommend this facility
continue a First Provisional license.
